key_title: Key to the species of Oxalis

source.author: Conn, B.J.; Jeanes, J.A.; Richards, P.G.
source.title: Oxalidaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: Modified from: Conn, B.J.; Jeanes, J.A.; Richards, P.G. (1999). Oxalidaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Aerial stem and branches absent or much reduced; leaves and peduncles radical or appearing so
Aerial stem and branches present, erect, ascending or creeping; leaves axillary, often whorled; peduncles axillary
Petals yellow or pale orange-fawn (red-veined in Oxalis obtusa)
Petals pale mauve, reddish, pink, purple, or white
Annual herb; petals 2.5–4 mm long; capsules readily produced in Australia
Perennial herbs; petals 10–25 mm long; capsules not produced in Australia
Inflorescences 1-flowered; bulbs deeply pitted and irregularly angled
Inflorescences (13–)30-flowered; bulbs more or less smooth
Petioles cylindric in cross-section, without wings
Petioles dorso-ventrally compressed and narrowly-winged
Leaflets mostly 4 (but juvenile plants often with 3 leaflets)
Leaflets 3
Inflorescences 1-flowered; sepals without calli
Inflorescences (1–)2-many-flowered (if ever 1-flowered, then sepals with calli); sepals with or without calli
Petioles sparsely covered with long hairs; petals 6–11 mm long, white; native herb of moist montane to alpine habitats
Petioles densely covered with simple white hairs; petals 10–40 mm long, pink to purple, sometimes white or yellow at base; weed of lawns and disturbed sites
Plant producing many small bulbils
Plant not producing bulbils
Bulbils produced from old bulbs on stolons
Bulbils sessile on old bulbs
Leaflets obcordate, narrowly notched, apices of lobes usually less than 12 mm apart; inflorescences 1–2(–3)-flowered
Leaflets c. deltoid, widely incised to form divergent lobes (?fishtail-shaped?) with apices 12–75 mm apart; inflorescences 6–14-flowered
Petals pink; lower surface of leaflets with many conspicuous orange-brown calli present; inflorescence corymbose
Petals white (possibly with a faint bluish tinge); leaflets with calli absent; inflorescence umbellate
Inflorescences 1-flowered; leaflets c. linear to narrow-cuneate, usually conduplicate
Inflorescences 4–15 (–30)-flowered; leaflets broadly obovate to nearly rhombic
Leaflets only minutely emarginate; petals rose-pink
Leaflets emarginate; petals white with red-purple margin (in bud), very rarely rose-pink
Rhizome stout and woody; bulbs absent; apex of sepals with 2 calli
Rhizome slender or thickened but not woody, not woody; bulbs present, ovoid to globose; apex of sepals lacking calli
Petals 14–30 mm long, usually mauve, pink or purplish, yellow or green at base; bulbs (and sometimes bulbils) present
Petals to c. 13 mm long, white or yellow; bulbs and bulbils absent
Leaflets linear, deeply bifurcate to the middle or beyond; bulbils formed on old bulb
Leaflets oblong-cuneate or obcordate, emarginate or if linear then never bifurcate; bulbils formed on rhizome and sometimes in leaf-axils (O. incarnata)
Stem glabrous; leaflets 8–20 mm wide, mostly broadly obcordate; corolla very pale lilac or pale pinkish-purple, greenish at base
Stem hairy; leaflets 1.3–5(–7) mm wide, linear, oblong, obovate or cuneate; corolla bright pink or purplish, yellow at base

Stem slightly woody, 1–2.2 mm wide; petioles usually 1–2(–5) mm long, much shorter than leaves; leaflets 3–5(–7) mm wide; lower surface of leaflets copiously dotted with glands, lacking blister-like epidermal cells
Stems wiry, 0.4–0.8 mm wide; petioles 4–22 mm long, petioles as long as leaves or exceeding leaves; leaflets 1.3–2 mm wide; lower surface of leaflets lacking glands, with blister-like epidermal cells
Annual herb; petals only slightly longer than calyx; capsules 3–5 mm long; seeds more or less spherical, with apiculate ends
Perennial herbs (or some forms of O. corniculata annual); petals usually much longer than calyx; capsules > 5 mm long or if shorter then petals white; seeds flattened
Hairs on stem and branches mostly antrorse (sometimes stems virtually glabrous in O. exilis); stipules conspicuous, not truncate (or sometimes truncate in O. exilis)
Hairs on stem and branches mostly spreading and/or retrorse; stipules either inconspicuous, or membranous and truncate
Seeds almost smooth to shallowly and transversely ridged; fruits with at least some patent septate hairs present

Seeds strongly transversely ridged; fruit without patent septate hairs (or if sometimes present as in O. exilis and O. rubens, then stems either usually rooting at nodes, or fruit to 24 mm long and 3–4 mm wide)
Seed ridges with distinctive white blotches and stripes; stems glabrescent
Seed ridges uniformly coloured; stems glabrescent to densely hairy

Plants not rooting at nodes or only proximally rooting at nodes, never forming mats; most inflorescences (2–)3–6-flowered, often umbel-like; fruits 10–13 mm long; stems 0.7–0.8 mm wide (white-ridged seed form of Oxalis corniculata)
Plants readily rooting at most nodes, often forming mats; inflorescence 1–2-flowered; fruits 6.5–8 mm long; stems 0.5–0.7 mm wide (disturbed site form of Oxalis exilis)

Seeds with U-shaped grooves and rounded to subtruncate ridges (in cross-section); stem and branches glabrous to sparsely hairy; leaflets rather glaucous; stems, branches and petioles often at least partly reddish; fruit 13–24 mm long, often thick in middle; plants mostly of coastal dunes

Seeds with V-shaped grooves and obtuse ridges (in cross-section) or ridges few and inconspicuous; stem and branches sparsely to densely hairy; stem, branches and leaves green to blue-green; fruit short and broad, or if longer (to 16 mm) then straight-sided; habitat various, but not known from coastal dunes

Fruit short and broad, 5–6.5 (–10) mm long, 2–3 mm diam., with simple hairs, occasionally with some patent septate hairs; apex tapering; inflorescence 1(–2)-flowered; stems creeping or ascending, often rooting at nodes

Fruit moderately long, 8–30 mm long, 2.5–5 mm diam., septate hairs absent; apex abruptly narrowed; inflorescence (1–)2–3(–6)-flowered; stems ascending to erect, occasionally creeping, rarely rooting at nodes
Flower solitary, white; fruit ovoid to globular, 4–5 mm long, glabrous; wet montane or subalpine forests and heathlands
Flowers 1–6, yellow; fruit subglobose to cylindric, more than 6 mm long, retrorse- hairy
Fruit relatively short and stout, usually 7–9 mm long, c. 3 mm diam.; branches long and trailing; leaflets usually densely hairy
Fruit long and relatively narrow, usually 7–20 mm long, 1.5–3 mm diam.; branches erect or trailing; leaflets densely hairy or glabrescent
Stipules obvious, 2–3 mm long, truncate; taproot, if present, not stout and woody
Stipules inconspicous, 1–1.5 mm long, keeled; taproot stout and woody
